contents.name: 28M35x Concerto
contents.desc: 28M35x Concerto

content.name: Minimal
content.desc: This example has a fairly minimal .cfg which is set up for a static application where all objects are defined statically (via configuration tool and/or target structures). Dynamic memory allocation has been disabled. The .cfg file creates a single task which has a couple of print statements and a Task_sleep() call.

content.name: Typical
content.desc: This example has a .cfg populated with a typical set of options and parameters. This .cfg file is a good starting point for many applications. Dyanamic memory allocation and runtime create of is supported. Unlike the 'Minimal' example, the single task is created at runtime using the Task_create() API.

contents.name: Generic Examples
contents.desc: Generic SYS/BIOS Examples. These examples are not optimized for code and data memory usage and may not build on platforms with memory constraints.

content.name: Benchmark Example
content.desc: This example gathers and prints benchmark timing data for some representative SYS/BIOS APIs.

content.name: C++ Example (bigtime)
content.desc: In this program, C++ is used to create a real-time clock/calendar.

content.name: Clock Example
content.desc: The clock example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Clock module to create one-shot and periodic Clock Instances. Clock Instances are essentially functions that run after a certain number of Clock ticks.

content.name: Error Example
content.desc: This example shows how to use Error_Blocks to catch runtime errors. An Error_Block is passed to Task_create() and then checked for create failure. When no Error_Block is passed, the application will terminate when an error occurs. The error.cfg file shows how to plug an error hook.

content.name: Event Example
content.desc: The event example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Event module. The ti.sysbios.knl.Event module solves the 'Wait on Multiple' problem. In this example a reader task waits on several events.

content.name: Hello Example
content.desc: The hello example serves as a basic sanity check program for SYS/BIOS. It demonstrates how to print the string 'hello world' to stdout.

content.name: Log Example
content.desc: This module shows how to use Log_info(), Log_error() and Log_warning() in a simple application. It shows how to enable USER1 logs for the Task module in the cfg file.

content.name: Memory Example
content.desc: This example shows the use of xdc.runtime.Memory module and different xdc.runtime.IHeap implementations to manage memory. A system heap is created statically using ti.sysbios.heaps.HeapMem.

content.name: Small Example
content.desc: This simple example uses the Clock module to periodically post a software interrupt (Swi), and increments counters. The configuration disables non-essential and debug-related SYS/BIOS features to reduce the application memory footprint.

content.name: Static Example
content.desc: The static example focuses on SYS/BIOS configuration. It shows how to use and configure various modules, create static Instances and modify Program level configuration parameters.

content.name: Swi Example
content.desc: The swi example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Swi module. It demonstrates how the various Swi APIs work.

content.name: Task Mutex Example
content.desc: This example shows the use of two tasks and one semaphore to protect data access.

content.desc: This example shows how to use Error_Blocks to catch runtime errors. An Error_Block is passed to Task_create() and then checked for create failure. When no Error_Block is passed, the application will terminate when an error occurs. The error.cfg file shows how to plug an error hook.

content.name: Event Example
content.desc: The event example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Event module. The ti.sysbios.knl.Event module solves the 'Wait on Multiple' problem. In this example a reader task waits on several events.

content.name: Hello Example
content.desc: The hello example serves as a basic sanity check program for SYS/BIOS. It demonstrates how to print the string 'hello world' to stdout.

content.name: Log Example
content.desc: This module shows how to use Log_info(), Log_error() and Log_warning() in a simple application. It shows how to enable USER1 logs for the Task module in the cfg file.

content.name: Memory Example
content.desc: This example shows the use of xdc.runtime.Memory module and different xdc.runtime.IHeap implementations to manage memory. A system heap is created statically using ti.sysbios.heaps.HeapMem.

content.name: Small Example
content.desc: This simple example uses the Clock module to periodically post a software interrupt (Swi), and increments counters. The configuration disables non-essential and debug-related SYS/BIOS features to reduce the application memory footprint.

content.name: Static Example
content.desc: The static example focuses on SYS/BIOS configuration. It shows how to use and configure various modules, create static Instances and modify Program level configuration parameters.

content.name: Swi Example
content.desc: The swi example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Swi module. It demonstrates how the various Swi APIs work.

content.name: Task Mutex Example
content.desc: This example shows the use of two tasks and one semaphore to protect data access.

content.name: Minimal
content.desc: This example has a fairly minimal .cfg which is set up for a static application where all objects are defined statically (via configuration tool and/or target structures). Dynamic memory allocation has been disabled. The .cfg file creates a single task which has a couple of print statements and a Task_sleep() call.

content.name: Typical
content.desc: This example has a .cfg populated with a typical set of options and parameters. This .cfg file is a good starting point for many applications. Dyanamic memory allocation and runtime create of is supported. Unlike the 'Minimal' example, the single task is created at runtime using the Task_create() API.

content.desc: The event example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Event module. The ti.sysbios.knl.Event module solves the 'Wait on Multiple' problem. In this example a reader task waits on several events.

content.name: Hello Example
content.desc: The hello example serves as a basic sanity check program for SYS/BIOS. It demonstrates how to print the string 'hello world' to stdout.

content.name: Log Example
content.desc: This module shows how to use Log_info(), Log_error() and Log_warning() in a simple application. It shows how to enable USER1 logs for the Task module in the cfg file.

content.name: Memory Example
content.desc: This example shows the use of xdc.runtime.Memory module and different xdc.runtime.IHeap implementations to manage memory. A system heap is created statically using ti.sysbios.heaps.HeapMem.

content.name: Small Example
content.desc: This simple example uses the Clock module to periodically post a software interrupt (Swi), and increments counters. The configuration disables non-essential and debug-related SYS/BIOS features to reduce the application memory footprint.

content.name: Task Mutex Example
content.desc: This example shows the use of two tasks and one semaphore to protect data access.

content.desc: This module shows how to use Log_info(), Log_error() and Log_warning() in a simple application. It shows how to enable USER1 logs for the Task module in the cfg file.

content.name: Memory Example
content.desc: This example shows the use of xdc.runtime.Memory module and different xdc.runtime.IHeap implementations to manage memory. A system heap is created statically using ti.sysbios.heaps.HeapMem.

content.name: Small Example
content.desc: This simple example uses the Clock module to periodically post a software interrupt (Swi), and increments counters. The configuration disables non-essential and debug-related SYS/BIOS features to reduce the application memory footprint.

content.name: Static Example
content.desc: The static example focuses on SYS/BIOS configuration. It shows how to use and configure various modules, create static Instances and modify Program level configuration parameters.

content.name: Swi Example
content.desc: The swi example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Swi module. It demonstrates how the various Swi APIs work.

content.name: Task Mutex Example
content.desc: This example shows the use of two tasks and one semaphore to protect data access.

content.name: Minimal
content.desc: This example has a fairly minimal .cfg which is set up for a static application where all objects are defined statically (via configuration tool and/or target structures). Dynamic memory allocation has been disabled. The .cfg file creates a single task which has a couple of print statements and a Task_sleep() call.

content.name: Typical
content.desc: This example has a .cfg populated with a typical set of options and parameters. This .cfg file is a good starting point for many applications. Dyanamic memory allocation and runtime create of is supported. Unlike the 'Minimal' example, the single task is created at runtime using the Task_create() API.

content.name: Minimal
content.desc: This example has a fairly minimal .cfg which is set up for a static application where all objects are defined statically (via configuration tool and/or target structures). Dynamic memory allocation has been disabled. The .cfg file creates a single task which has a couple of print statements and a Task_sleep() call.

content.name: Typical
content.desc: This example has a .cfg populated with a typical set of options and parameters. This .cfg file is a good starting point for many applications. Dyanamic memory allocation and runtime create of is supported. Unlike the 'Minimal' example, the single task is created at runtime using the Task_create() API.

content.name: Error Example
content.desc: This example shows how to use Error_Blocks to catch runtime errors. An Error_Block is passed to Task_create() and then checked for create failure. When no Error_Block is passed, the application will terminate when an error occurs. The error.cfg file shows how to plug an error hook.

content.name: Event Example
content.desc: The event example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Event module. The ti.sysbios.knl.Event module solves the 'Wait on Multiple' problem. In this example a reader task waits on several events.

content.desc: The hello example serves as a basic sanity check program for SYS/BIOS. It demonstrates how to print the string 'hello world' to stdout.

content.desc: This simple example uses the Clock module to periodically post a software interrupt (Swi), and increments counters. The configuration disables non-essential and debug-related SYS/BIOS features to reduce the application memory footprint.

content.desc: A 28x specific example which shows how to handle (simulated) peripheral interrupts from the PIE

content.name: Swi Example
content.desc: A 28x specific example which uses an Swi function and an Idle function to print to a log buffer

content.name: Task Example
content.desc: A 28x specific example which uses an task to print to a log buffer

contents.name: Generic Examples
contents.desc: Generic SYS/BIOS Examples. These examples are not optimized for code and data memory usage and may not build on platforms with memory constraints.

content.name: Benchmark Example
content.desc: This example gathers and prints benchmark timing data for some representative SYS/BIOS APIs.

content.name: C++ Example (bigtime)
content.desc: In this program, C++ is used to create a real-time clock/calendar.

content.name: Clock Example
content.desc: The clock example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Clock module to create one-shot and periodic Clock Instances. Clock Instances are essentially functions that run after a certain number of Clock ticks.

content.name: Error Example
content.desc: This example shows how to use Error_Blocks to catch runtime errors. An Error_Block is passed to Task_create() and then checked for create failure. When no Error_Block is passed, the application will terminate when an error occurs. The error.cfg file shows how to plug an error hook.

content.name: Event Example
content.desc: The event example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Event module. The ti.sysbios.knl.Event module solves the 'Wait on Multiple' problem. In this example a reader task waits on several events.

content.name: Hello Example
content.desc: The hello example serves as a basic sanity check program for SYS/BIOS. It demonstrates how to print the string 'hello world' to stdout.

content.name: Log Example
content.desc: This module shows how to use Log_info(), Log_error() and Log_warning() in a simple application. It shows how to enable USER1 logs for the Task module in the cfg file.

content.name: Memory Example
content.desc: This example shows the use of xdc.runtime.Memory module and different xdc.runtime.IHeap implementations to manage memory. A system heap is created statically using ti.sysbios.heaps.HeapMem.

content.name: Small Example
content.desc: This simple example uses the Clock module to periodically post a software interrupt (Swi), and increments counters. The configuration disables non-essential and debug-related SYS/BIOS features to reduce the application memory footprint.

content.name: Static Example
content.desc: The static example focuses on SYS/BIOS configuration. It shows how to use and configure various modules, create static Instances and modify Program level configuration parameters.

content.name: Swi Example
content.desc: The swi example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Swi module. It demonstrates how the various Swi APIs work.

content.name: Task Mutex Example
content.desc: This example shows the use of two tasks and one semaphore to protect data access.

content.name: Minimal
content.desc: This example has a fairly minimal .cfg which is set up for a static application where all objects are defined statically (via configuration tool and/or target structures). Dynamic memory allocation has been disabled. The .cfg file creates a single task which has a couple of print statements and a Task_sleep() call.

content.name: Typical
content.desc: This example has a .cfg populated with a typical set of options and parameters. This .cfg file is a good starting point for many applications. Dyanamic memory allocation and runtime create of is supported. Unlike the 'Minimal' example, the single task is created at runtime using the Task_create() API.

content.desc: The clock example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Clock module to create one-shot and periodic Clock Instances. Clock Instances are essentially functions that run after a certain number of Clock ticks.

content.name: Error Example
content.desc: This example shows how to use Error_Blocks to catch runtime errors. An Error_Block is passed to Task_create() and then checked for create failure. When no Error_Block is passed, the application will terminate when an error occurs. The error.cfg file shows how to plug an error hook.

content.name: Event Example
content.desc: The event example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Event module. The ti.sysbios.knl.Event module solves the 'Wait on Multiple' problem. In this example a reader task waits on several events.

content.name: Hello Example
content.desc: The hello example serves as a basic sanity check program for SYS/BIOS. It demonstrates how to print the string 'hello world' to stdout.

content.name: Log Example
content.desc: This module shows how to use Log_info(), Log_error() and Log_warning() in a simple application. It shows how to enable USER1 logs for the Task module in the cfg file.

content.name: Memory Example
content.desc: This example shows the use of xdc.runtime.Memory module and different xdc.runtime.IHeap implementations to manage memory. A system heap is created statically using ti.sysbios.heaps.HeapMem.

content.name: Small Example
content.desc: This simple example uses the Clock module to periodically post a software interrupt (Swi), and increments counters. The configuration disables non-essential and debug-related SYS/BIOS features to reduce the application memory footprint.

content.name: Static Example
content.desc: The static example focuses on SYS/BIOS configuration. It shows how to use and configure various modules, create static Instances and modify Program level configuration parameters.

content.name: Swi Example
content.desc: The swi example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Swi module. It demonstrates how the various Swi APIs work.

content.name: Task Mutex Example
content.desc: This example shows the use of two tasks and one semaphore to protect data access.

content.name: Minimal
content.desc: This example has a fairly minimal .cfg which is set up for a static application where all objects are defined statically (via configuration tool and/or target structures). Dynamic memory allocation has been disabled. The .cfg file creates a single task which has a couple of print statements and a Task_sleep() call.

content.name: Typical
content.desc: This example has a .cfg populated with a typical set of options and parameters. This .cfg file is a good starting point for many applications. Dyanamic memory allocation and runtime create of is supported. Unlike the 'Minimal' example, the single task is created at runtime using the Task_create() API.

content.desc: The hello example serves as a basic sanity check program for SYS/BIOS. It demonstrates how to print the string 'hello world' to stdout.

content.name: Log Example
content.desc: This module shows how to use Log_info(), Log_error() and Log_warning() in a simple application. It shows how to enable USER1 logs for the Task module in the cfg file.

content.name: Memory Example
content.desc: This example shows the use of xdc.runtime.Memory module and different xdc.runtime.IHeap implementations to manage memory. A system heap is created statically using ti.sysbios.heaps.HeapMem.

content.name: Small Example
content.desc: This simple example uses the Clock module to periodically post a software interrupt (Swi), and increments counters. The configuration disables non-essential and debug-related SYS/BIOS features to reduce the application memory footprint.

content.name: Static Example
content.desc: The static example focuses on SYS/BIOS configuration. It shows how to use and configure various modules, create static Instances and modify Program level configuration parameters.

content.name: Swi Example
content.desc: The swi example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Swi module. It demonstrates how the various Swi APIs work.

content.name: Task Mutex Example
content.desc: This example shows the use of two tasks and one semaphore to protect data access.

content.name: Minimal
content.desc: This example has a fairly minimal .cfg which is set up for a static application where all objects are defined statically (via configuration tool and/or target structures). Dynamic memory allocation has been disabled. The .cfg file creates a single task which has a couple of print statements and a Task_sleep() call.

content.name: Typical
content.desc: This example has a .cfg populated with a typical set of options and parameters. This .cfg file is a good starting point for many applications. content.desc: This example shows the use of xdc.runtime.Memory module and different xdc.runtime.IHeap implementations to manage memory. A system heap is created statically using ti.sysbios.heaps.HeapMem.

content.name: Small Example
content.desc: This simple example uses the Clock module to periodically post a software interrupt (Swi), and increments counters. The configuration disables non-essential and debug-related SYS/BIOS features to reduce the application memory footprint.

content.name: Static Example
content.desc: The static example focuses on SYS/BIOS configuration. It shows how to use and configure various modules, create static Instances and modify Program level configuration parameters.

content.name: Swi Example
content.desc: The swi example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Swi module. It demonstrates how the various Swi APIs work.

content.name: Task Mutex Example
content.desc: This example shows the use of two tasks and one semaphore to protect data access.

content.name: Minimal
content.desc: This example has a fairly minimal .cfg which is set up for a static application where all objects are defined statically (via configuration tool and/or target structures). Dynamic memory allocation has been disabled. The .cfg file creates a single task which has a couple of print statements and a Task_sleep() call.

content.name: Typical
content.desc: This example has a .cfg populated with a typical set of options and parameters. This .cfg file is a good starting point for many applications. Dyanamic memory allocation and runtime create of is supported. Unlike the 'Minimal' example, the single task is created at runtime using the Task_create() API.

content.desc: The swi example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Swi module. It demonstrates how the various Swi APIs work.

content.name: Task Mutex Example
content.desc: This example shows the use of two tasks and one semaphore to protect data access.

content.name: Minimal
content.desc: This example has a fairly minimal .cfg which is set up for a static application where all objects are defined statically (via configuration tool and/or target structures). Dynamic memory allocation has been disabled. The .cfg file creates a single task which has a couple of print statements and a Task_sleep() call.

content.name: Typical
content.desc: This example has a .cfg populated with a typical set of options and parameters. This .cfg file is a good starting point for many applications. Dyanamic memory allocation and runtime create of is supported. Unlike the 'Minimal' example, the single task is created at runtime using the Task_create() API.

contents.name: 28x Examples
contents.desc: 28x specific SYS/BIOS Examples

content.name: Idle Example
content.desc: A 28x specific example which uses an Idle function to print to standard out and a log buffer

content.name: PIE Interrupt Example
content.desc: A 28x specific example which shows how to handle (simulated) peripheral interrupts from the PIE

content.name: Swi Example
content.desc: A 28x specific example which uses an Swi function and an Idle function to print to a log buffer

content.name: Task Example
content.desc: A 28x specific example which uses an task to print to a log buffer

contents.name: Generic Examples
contents.desc: Generic SYS/BIOS Examples. These examples are not optimized for code and data memory usage and may not build on platforms with memory constraints.

content.name: Benchmark Example
content.desc: This example gathers and prints benchmark timing data for some representative SYS/BIOS APIs.

content.name: C++ Example (bigtime)
content.desc: In this program, C++ is used to create a real-time clock/calendar.

content.name: Clock Example
content.desc: The clock example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Clock module to create one-shot and periodic Clock Instances. Clock Instances are essentially functions that run after a certain number of Clock ticks.

content.name: Error Example
content.desc: This example shows how to use Error_Blocks to catch runtime errors. An Error_Block is passed to Task_create() and then checked for create failure. When no Error_Block is passed, the application will terminate when an error occurs. The error.cfg file shows how to plug an error hook.

content.name: Event Example
content.desc: The event example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Event module. The ti.sysbios.knl.Event module solves the 'Wait on Multiple' problem. In this example a reader task waits on several events.

content.name: Hello Example
content.desc: The hello example serves as a basic sanity check program for SYS/BIOS. It demonstrates how to print the string 'hello world' to stdout.

content.name: Log Example
content.desc: This module shows how to use Log_info(), Log_error() and Log_warning() in a simple application. It shows how to enable USER1 logs for the Task module in the cfg file.

content.name: Memory Example
content.desc: This example shows the use of xdc.runtime.Memory module and different xdc.runtime.IHeap implementations to manage memory. A system heap is created statically using ti.sysbios.heaps.HeapMem.

content.name: Small Example
content.desc: This simple example uses the Clock module to periodically post a software interrupt (Swi), and increments counters. The configuration disables non-essential and debug-related SYS/BIOS features to reduce the application memory footprint.

content.name: Static Example
content.desc: The static example focuses on SYS/BIOS configuration. It shows how to use and configure various modules, create static Instances and modify Program level configuration parameters.

content.name: Swi Example
content.desc: The swi example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Swi module. It demonstrates how the various Swi APIs work.

content.name: Task Mutex Example
content.desc: This example shows the use of two tasks and one semaphore to protect data access.

content.name: Minimal
content.desc: This example has a fairly minimal .cfg which is set up for a static application where all objects are defined statically (via configuration tool and/or target structures). Dynamic memory allocation has been disabled. The .cfg file creates a single task which has a couple of print statements and a Task_sleep() call.

content.name: Typical
content.desc: This example has a .cfg populated with a typical set of options and parameters. This .cfg file is a good starting point for many applications. Dyanamic memory allocation and runtime create of is supported. Unlike the 'Minimal' example, the single task is created at runtime using the Task_create() API.

contents.name: Generic Examples
contents.desc: Generic SYS/BIOS Examples. These examples are not optimized for code and data memory usage and may not build on platforms with memory constraints.

content.name: Benchmark Example
content.desc: This example gathers and prints benchmark timing data for some representative SYS/BIOS APIs.

content.name: C++ Example (bigtime)
content.desc: In this program, C++ is used to create a real-time clock/calendar.

content.name: Clock Example
content.desc: The clock example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Clock module to create one-shot and periodic Clock Instances. Clock Instances are essentially functions that run after a certain number of Clock ticks.

content.name: Error Example
content.desc: This example shows how to use Error_Blocks to catch runtime errors. An Error_Block is passed to Task_create() and then checked for create failure. When no Error_Block is passed, the application will terminate when an error occurs. The error.cfg file shows how to plug an error hook.

content.name: Event Example
content.desc: The event example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Event module. The ti.sysbios.knl.Event module solves the 'Wait on Multiple' problem. In this example a reader task waits on several events.

content.name: Hello Example
content.desc: The hello example serves as a basic sanity check program for SYS/BIOS. It demonstrates how to print the string 'hello world' to stdout.

content.name: Log Example
content.desc: This module shows how to use Log_info(), Log_error() and Log_warning() in a simple application. It shows how to enable USER1 logs for the Task module in the cfg file.

content.name: Memory Example
content.desc: This example shows the use of xdc.runtime.Memory module and different xdc.runtime.IHeap implementations to manage memory. A system heap is created statically using ti.sysbios.heaps.HeapMem.

content.name: Small Example
content.desc: This simple example uses the Clock module to periodically post a software interrupt (Swi), and increments counters. The configuration disables non-essential and debug-related SYS/BIOS features to reduce the application memory footprint.

content.name: Static Example
content.desc: The static example focuses on SYS/BIOS configuration. It shows how to use and configure various modules, create static Instances and modify Program level configuration parameters.

content.name: Swi Example
content.desc: The swi example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Swi module. It demonstrates how the various Swi APIs work.

content.name: Task Mutex Example
content.desc: This example shows the use of two tasks and one semaphore to protect data access.

contents.desc: Generic C66xx Device

content.desc: This simple example uses the Clock module to periodically post a software interrupt (Swi), and increments counters. The configuration disables non-essential and debug-related SYS/BIOS features to reduce the application memory footprint.

content.name: Static Example
content.desc: The static example focuses on SYS/BIOS configuration. It shows how to use and configure various modules, create static Instances and modify Program level configuration parameters.

content.name: Swi Example
content.desc: The swi example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Swi module. It demonstrates how the various Swi APIs work.

content.name: Task Mutex Example
content.desc: This example shows the use of two tasks and one semaphore to protect data access.

content.name: Minimal
content.desc: This example has a fairly minimal .cfg which is set up for a static application where all objects are defined statically (via configuration tool and/or target structures). Dynamic memory allocation has been disabled. The .cfg file creates a single task which has a couple of print statements and a Task_sleep() call.

content.name: Typical
content.desc: This example has a .cfg populated with a typical set of options and parameters. This .cfg file is a good starting point for many applications. Dyanamic memory allocation and runtime create of is supported. Unlike the 'Minimal' example, the single task is created at runtime using the Task_create() API.

contents.name: Generic Examples
contents.desc: Generic SYS/BIOS Examples. These examples are not optimized for code and data memory usage and may not build on platforms with memory constraints.

content.name: Benchmark Example
content.desc: This example gathers and prints benchmark timing data for some representative SYS/BIOS APIs.

content.name: C++ Example (bigtime)
content.desc: In this program, C++ is used to create a real-time clock/calendar.

content.name: Clock Example
content.desc: The clock example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Clock module to create one-shot and periodic Clock Instances. Clock Instances are essentially functions that run after a certain number of Clock ticks.

content.name: Error Example
content.desc: This example shows how to use Error_Blocks to catch runtime errors. An Error_Block is passed to Task_create() and then checked for create failure. When no Error_Block is passed, the application will terminate when an error occurs. The error.cfg file shows how to plug an error hook.

content.name: Event Example
content.desc: The event example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Event module. The ti.sysbios.knl.Event module solves the 'Wait on Multiple' problem. In this example a reader task waits on several events.

content.name: Hello Example
content.desc: The hello example serves as a basic sanity check program for SYS/BIOS. It demonstrates how to print the string 'hello world' to stdout.

content.name: Log Example
content.desc: This module shows how to use Log_info(), Log_error() and Log_warning() in a simple application. It shows how to enable USER1 logs for the Task module in the cfg file.

content.name: Memory Example
content.desc: This example shows the use of xdc.runtime.Memory module and different xdc.runtime.IHeap implementations to manage memory. A system heap is created statically using ti.sysbios.heaps.HeapMem.

content.desc: This example shows the use of two tasks and one semaphore to protect data access.

content.desc: The event example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Event module. The ti.sysbios.knl.Event module solves the 'Wait on Multiple' problem. In this example a reader task waits on several events.

content.name: Hello Example
content.desc: The hello example serves as a basic sanity check program for SYS/BIOS. It demonstrates how to print the string 'hello world' to stdout.

content.name: Log Example
content.desc: This module shows how to use Log_info(), Log_error() and Log_warning() in a simple application. It shows how to enable USER1 logs for the Task module in the cfg file.

content.name: Memory Example
content.desc: This example shows the use of xdc.runtime.Memory module and different xdc.runtime.IHeap implementations to manage memory. A system heap is created statically using ti.sysbios.heaps.HeapMem.

content.name: Small Example
content.desc: This simple example uses the Clock module to periodically post a software interrupt (Swi), and increments counters. The configuration disables non-essential and debug-related SYS/BIOS features to reduce the application memory footprint.

content.name: Static Example
content.desc: The static example focuses on SYS/BIOS configuration. It shows how to use and configure various modules, create static Instances and modify Program level configuration parameters.

content.name: Swi Example
content.desc: The swi example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Swi module. It demonstrates how the various Swi APIs work.

content.name: Task Mutex Example
content.desc: This example shows the use of two tasks and one semaphore to protect data access.

content.name: Minimal
content.desc: This example has a fairly minimal .cfg which is set up for a static application where all objects are defined statically (via configuration tool and/or target structures). Dynamic memory allocation has been disabled. The .cfg file creates a single task which has a couple of print statements and a Task_sleep() call.

content.name: Typical
content.desc: This example has a .cfg populated with a typical set of options and parameters. This .cfg file is a good starting point for many applications. Dyanamic memory allocation and runtime create of is supported. Unlike the 'Minimal' example, the single task is created at runtime using the Task_create() API.

content.desc: In this program, C++ is used to create a real-time clock/calendar.

content.name: Clock Example
content.desc: The clock example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Clock module to create one-shot and periodic Clock Instances. Clock Instances are essentially functions that run after a certain number of Clock ticks.

content.name: Error Example
content.desc: This example shows how to use Error_Blocks to catch runtime errors. An Error_Block is passed to Task_create() and then checked for create failure. When no Error_Block is passed, the application will terminate when an error occurs. The error.cfg file shows how to plug an error hook.

content.name: Event Example
content.desc: The event example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Event module. The ti.sysbios.knl.Event module solves the 'Wait on Multiple' problem. In this example a reader task waits on several events.

content.name: Hello Example
content.desc: The hello example serves as a basic sanity check program for SYS/BIOS. It demonstrates how to print the string 'hello world' to stdout.

content.name: Log Example
content.desc: This module shows how to use Log_info(), Log_error() and Log_warning() in a simple application. It shows how to enable USER1 logs for the Task module in the cfg file.

content.name: Memory Example
content.desc: This example shows the use of xdc.runtime.Memory module and different xdc.runtime.IHeap implementations to manage memory. A system heap is created statically using ti.sysbios.heaps.HeapMem.

content.name: Small Example
content.desc: This simple example uses the Clock module to periodically post a software interrupt (Swi), and increments counters. The configuration disables non-essential and debug-related SYS/BIOS features to reduce the application memory footprint.

content.name: Static Example
content.desc: The static example focuses on SYS/BIOS configuration. It shows how to use and configure various modules, create static Instances and modify Program level configuration parameters.

content.name: Swi Example
content.desc: The swi example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Swi module. It demonstrates how the various Swi APIs work.

content.name: Task Mutex Example
content.desc: This example shows the use of two tasks and one semaphore to protect data access.

contents.name: C674x Floating-point DSP
contents.desc: C674x Floating-point DSP

content.name: Minimal
content.desc: This example has a fairly minimal .cfg which is set up for a static application where all objects are defined statically (via configuration tool and/or target structures). Dynamic memory allocation has been disabled. The .cfg file creates a single task which has a couple of print statements and a Task_sleep() call.

content.name: Typical
content.desc: This example has a .cfg populated with a typical set of options and parameters. This .cfg file is a good starting point for many applications. Dyanamic memory allocation and runtime create of is supported. Unlike the 'Minimal' example, the single task is created at runtime using the Task_create() API.

contents.desc: Generic SYS/BIOS Examples. These examples are not optimized for code and data memory usage and may not build on platforms with memory constraints.

content.desc: This example has a .cfg populated with a typical set of options and parameters. This .cfg file is a good starting point for many applications. Dyanamic memory allocation and runtime create of is supported. Unlike the 'Minimal' example, the single task is created at runtime using the Task_create() API.

contents.name: Generic Examples
contents.desc: Generic SYS/BIOS Examples. These examples are not optimized for code and data memory usage and may not build on platforms with memory constraints.

content.name: Benchmark Example
content.desc: This example gathers and prints benchmark timing data for some representative SYS/BIOS APIs.

content.name: C++ Example (bigtime)
content.desc: In this program, C++ is used to create a real-time clock/calendar.

content.name: Clock Example
content.desc: The clock example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Clock module to create one-shot and periodic Clock Instances. Clock Instances are essentially functions that run after a certain number of Clock ticks.

content.name: Error Example
content.desc: This example shows how to use Error_Blocks to catch runtime errors. An Error_Block is passed to Task_create() and then checked for create failure. When no Error_Block is passed, the application will terminate when an error occurs. The error.cfg file shows how to plug an error hook.

content.name: Event Example
content.desc: The event example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Event module. The ti.sysbios.knl.Event module solves the 'Wait on Multiple' problem. In this example a reader task waits on several events.

content.name: Hello Example
content.desc: The hello example serves as a basic sanity check program for SYS/BIOS. It demonstrates how to print the string 'hello world' to stdout.

content.name: Log Example
content.desc: This module shows how to use Log_info(), Log_error() and Log_warning() in a simple application. It shows how to enable USER1 logs for the Task module in the cfg file.

content.name: Memory Example
content.desc: This example shows the use of xdc.runtime.Memory module and different xdc.runtime.IHeap implementations to manage memory. A system heap is created statically using ti.sysbios.heaps.HeapMem.

content.name: Small Example
content.desc: This simple example uses the Clock module to periodically post a software interrupt (Swi), and increments counters. The configuration disables non-essential and debug-related SYS/BIOS features to reduce the application memory footprint.

content.name: Static Example
content.desc: The static example focuses on SYS/BIOS configuration. It shows how to use and configure various modules, create static Instances and modify Program level configuration parameters.

content.name: Swi Example
content.desc: The swi example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Swi module. It demonstrates how the various Swi APIs work.

content.name: Task Mutex Example
content.desc: This example shows the use of two tasks and one semaphore to protect data access.

content.desc: The swi example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Swi module. It demonstrates how the various Swi APIs work.

content.name: Task Mutex Example
content.desc: This example shows the use of two tasks and one semaphore to protect data access.

content.name: Minimal
content.desc: This example has a fairly minimal .cfg which is set up for a static application where all objects are defined statically (via configuration tool and/or target structures). Dynamic memory allocation has been disabled. The .cfg file creates a single task which has a couple of print statements and a Task_sleep() call.

content.name: Typical
content.desc: This example has a .cfg populated with a typical set of options and parameters. This .cfg file is a good starting point for many applications. Dyanamic memory allocation and runtime create of is supported. Unlike the 'Minimal' example, the single task is created at runtime using the Task_create() API.

contents.name: Generic Examples
contents.desc: Generic SYS/BIOS Examples. These examples are not optimized for code and data memory usage and may not build on platforms with memory constraints.

content.name: Benchmark Example
content.desc: This example gathers and prints benchmark timing data for some representative SYS/BIOS APIs.

content.name: C++ Example (bigtime)
content.desc: In this program, C++ is used to create a real-time clock/calendar.

content.name: Clock Example
content.desc: The clock example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Clock module to create one-shot and periodic Clock Instances. Clock Instances are essentially functions that run after a certain number of Clock ticks.

content.name: Error Example
content.desc: This example shows how to use Error_Blocks to catch runtime errors. An Error_Block is passed to Task_create() and then checked for create failure. When no Error_Block is passed, the application will terminate when an error occurs. The error.cfg file shows how to plug an error hook.

content.name: Event Example
content.desc: The event example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Event module. The ti.sysbios.knl.Event module solves the 'Wait on Multiple' problem. In this example a reader task waits on several events.

content.name: Hello Example
content.desc: The hello example serves as a basic sanity check program for SYS/BIOS. It demonstrates how to print the string 'hello world' to stdout.

content.name: Log Example
content.desc: This module shows how to use Log_info(), Log_error() and Log_warning() in a simple application. It shows how to enable USER1 logs for the Task module in the cfg file.

content.name: Memory Example
content.desc: This example shows the use of xdc.runtime.Memory module and different xdc.runtime.IHeap implementations to manage memory. A system heap is created statically using ti.sysbios.heaps.HeapMem.

content.name: Small Example
content.desc: This simple example uses the Clock module to periodically post a software interrupt (Swi), and increments counters. The configuration disables non-essential and debug-related SYS/BIOS features to reduce the application memory footprint.

content.name: Static Example
content.desc: The static example focuses on SYS/BIOS configuration. It shows how to use and configure various modules, create static Instances and modify Program level configuration parameters.

content.name: Swi Example
content.desc: The swi example shows how to use the ti.sysbios.knl.Swi module. It demonstrates how the various Swi APIs work.

content.name: Task Mutex Example
content.desc: This example shows the use of two tasks and one semaphore to protect data access.
